head.title: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

hedline.hl1: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

abstract.p: Paul Carlin letter on Peter Applebome's July 2 column on how to react to black man playing loud and offensive rap music at gas station pump holds issue is noise pollution rather than race (S)

block.p: Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.
Pollution is pollution, and a civilized person's dilemma seems always to be whether it is worth the risk to bring the offense to the polluter's attention (chances are slim for a civil response).
Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.
Pollution is pollution, and a civilized person's dilemma seems always to be whether it is worth the risk to bring the offense to the polluter's attention (chances are slim for a civil response).

The fact that the polluter in this case was black is negligible. That he was big is more to the point. (The prison guard touch is a bonus.) After years of following trash-dumping cars to a red light to talk, confronting subway smokers, etc., I've concluded, astonishingly, that if they look dangerous, they very well might be dangerous!
So if someone litters, or uses the N-word, or blasts their profane music at our child (in other words, ''pollutes''), we use common sense: approach if they look approachable. Your call on the gauge.

I'm not minimizing the role race plays in American society. I'm just saying that the role, in this case, is minimal. Unless the author would have felt more comfortable approaching a big white filth-blasting prison guard. In which case, that's race-ism, and I don't get it.
